title: Taylor Swift vs. the manosphere
content:
No Girls Allowed

NEW: an ideological divide is emerging between young men and women in many countries around the world.

I think this one of the most important social trends unfolding today, and provides the answer to several puzzles.

â€” John Burn-Murdoch (@jburnmurdoch)
Jan 26, 2024

Over the weekend, the always-excellent John Burn-Murdoch, over at The Financial Times, posted an alarming bit of demographic analysis that has now gone very viral. Itâ€™s from a column Burn-Murdoch wrote titled, â€œA New Global Gender Divide Is Emerging,â€ which shows a tremendous political gap forming between young men and women around the world.

Burn-Murdoch followed up the column with a lengthy thread on X hypothesizing as to what may be causing this gap and thousands of other users have offered up their own diagnoses, as well: Smartphones, video games, economic inequality, lack of education, an over-correction post-#MeToo.

Interestingly enough, though, the bulk of Burn-Murdochâ€™s reporting focuses on South Korea, the US, Germany, the UK, Spain, Poland, China, and Tunisia. Which, aside from China and Tunisia, were all countries I worked in, covering elections and far-right radicalization, in and around the time period those countriesâ€™ respective political gender gaps began widening. Iâ€™m not saying I have a tremendously in-depth understanding of, say, Polish toxic masculinity, but I did spend several days there following around white nationalist rappers and Catholic fundamentalist football fans. And, in South Korea, I worked on a project about radical feminists and their activism against the countryâ€™s equivalent of 4chan, Ilbe Storehouse.

In fact, between 2015-2019, I visited over 20 countries, essentially asking the same question: Where do bad men here hangout online? Which has given me a near-encyclopedic directory in my head, unfortunately, of international 4chan knock-offs. In Spain, itâ€™s a car forum that doxxes rape victims called ForoCoches. In France, itâ€™s a gaming forum that organized rallies for Marine Le Pen called Jeux Video. In Japan, itâ€™s 2channel. In Brazil, itâ€™s Dogolachan. And most, if not all, of these spaces pre-date any sort of modern social movement like #MeToo â€” or even the invention of the smartphone.

But the mainstream acceptance of the culture from these sites is new. Though I donâ€™t actually think the mystery of â€œwhy now?â€ is that much of a mystery. While working in Europe, I came to understand that these sites and their culture war campaigns like Gamergate were a sort of emerging form of digital hooliganism. Nothing they were doing was new, but their understanding how to network online was novel. And in places like the UK, it actually became more and more common in the late-2010s to see Pepe the Frog cosplayers marching alongside far-right football clubs. In the US, we donâ€™t have the same sports culture, but the end result has been the same. The nerds and the jocks eventually aligned in the streets. The anime nazis were simply early adopters and the tough guys with guns and zip ties just needed time to adapt to new technology. And, unlike the pre-internet age, unmoderated large social platforms give them an infinitely-scalable recruitment radius. They donâ€™t have to hide in backrooms anymore.

Much of the digital playbook fueling this recruitment for our new(ish) international masculinist movement was created by ISIS, the true early adopters for this sort of thing. Though it took about a decade for the West to really embrace it. But nowadays, it is not uncommon to see trad accounts sharing memes about â€œmotherhood,â€ that are pretty much identical to the Disney Princess photoshops ISIS brides would post on Tumblr to advertise their new life in Syria. And, even more darkly, just this week, a Trump supporter in Pennsylvania beheaded his father and uploaded it to YouTube, in a video where he ranted about the woke left and President Biden. Online extremism is a flat circle.

The biggest similarity, though, is in what I call cultural encoding. For ISIS, this was about constantly labeling everything that threatened their influence as a symptom of the decadent, secular West.

For our new International League Of Unfuckable Conservative Men, it is, increasingly, about labeling everything that threatens them as feminine and, thus, bad. This is why you only ever see them rant about women journalists â€” well, usually itâ€™s just The Washington Postâ€™s Taylor Lorenz tbh. This is also why theyâ€™re always angry about whatever wild shit random teenage girls are posting TikTok. And this why they invented the concept of â€œsimping,â€ the minute sites like OnlyFans began giving direct financial power to sex workers. Because they see masculinity as unquestionable strength and anything that threatens that must be eliminated. And this why theyâ€™re all losing their minds over Taylor Swift right now.

(X.com/jeremykauffman)

Taylor Swift, an extremely affluent blonde, blue-eyed white woman who writes country-inflected pop music and is dating a football player headed for the Super Bowl. She should be a resounding victory for these guys. Doesnâ€™t get more American than that. But due to an actually very funny glitch in how they see the world, sheâ€™s actually a huge threat.

Pop culture, according to the right wing, should be frivolous. Because before the internet, it was something sold to girls by corporations run by powerful men. Famous pop stars through the ages, like Frank Sinatra, Americaâ€™s first Justin Bieber, or The Beatles, the One Direction of their time, would be canonized as Great by Serious Men after history had forgotten they rocketed to success as their generationâ€™s Tumblr Sexymen. But from the 2000s onward, thanks to an increasingly powerful digital public square, young women and people of color were able to have more influence in mainstream culture and also accumulate more financial power from it. And after Barack Obamaâ€™s 2008 presidential campaign was able to connect this new form of pop influence to both liberal progressive politics and, also, social media, well, conservatives realized they had to catch up and fast. And the fastest way to do that is to try and smash the whole thing by dismissing it as feminine.

Pop music? Itâ€™s for girls. Social media? Itâ€™s for girls. Democrats? Girls. Taylor Swift? Girls and also a government psyop. But this line of thinking has no limit. It poisons everything. If Swift manages to make it to the Super Bowl, well, that has to become feminine too. And at a certain point, the whole thing falls apart because, honestly, you just sound like an insane loser.

The following is a paid ad. If youâ€™re interested in advertising, email me at ryan@garbageday.email and letâ€™s talk. Thanks!

For some election-year readingâ€¦

Over the past few years, FWIW has become the go-to newsletter for journalists and political operatives tracking digital tactics and trends in American politics. From interviews with the White House to investigations of shady right-wing content farms on Facebook, subscribe to FWIW to monitor the online forces impacting our elections.

Garbage Day Patch Notes

We caught yet another bug causing double charges. It seems like it only impacted a very small amount of subscribers, thankfully, but I want to talk a bit about it because itâ€™s something other newsletter writers should be aware of. And, also, Iâ€™m furious about it.

After leaving Substack, I luckily happened to come across some documentation from Ghost and a great post by writer Molly White about how you have to personally ask Substackâ€™s support team to remove their access to your Stripe account. If you donâ€™t, they can still take their 10% cut from your subscriptions, even though youâ€™re no longer using them as a host. Which is ridiculous and, frankly, predatory, considering Substack, itself, does not mention this anywhere.

To be as diplomatic as I can here, during the one-on-one conversation with Substackâ€™s support about removing this fee a, uh, miscommunication occurred. I thought I was explicit about what I wanted to happen, but, in talking to other writers who have left the site and dealt with this, itâ€™s apparently a real â€œwhatâ€™s the secret passwordâ€ situation in getting them to do this correctly. And so, I discovered over the weekend that Substack had left all of their subscriptions still active and simply removed their access, resulting in everyone having two concurrent subscriptions, one for Substack and one for Beehiiv. Beehiiv has been a huge help and ran a script to remove the double charges this morning. If you havenâ€™t been impacted, you shouldnâ€™t have to do anything. If youâ€™ve already emailed me about a double charge, donâ€™t worry, Iâ€™ll be contacting you soon. And if you have seen a double charge and havenâ€™t emailed me, just reply to this issue, and weâ€™ll get it sorted.

And if youâ€™re writer planning to leave Substack, you have to specifically ask for them to â€œcancel the subscriptions in Stripe, issue no refunds, and disconnect your Stripe account from Substack.â€ Even though itâ€™s worded as if theyâ€™re about to nuke all your readers, this is the correct choice in the decision tree. Good luck.

â€œARGâ€ Stands ForÂ â€œArgylle Reality Gameâ€

â€”by Adam Bumas

With all the â€œmovies are back!â€ moments weâ€™ve had in the past few years, thereâ€™s probably no actually going back again. Thatâ€™s why the movie Argylle, which opens in theaters Friday, canâ€™t just sell itself on being a funny spy movie full of hot celebrities. There has to be some kind of crucial, structural spoiler â€” a reason to get out to the theater that just reading the plot synopsis wonâ€™t fully satisfy.Â 

And the secrecy around Argylle has been a multi-stage operation. Originally, the marketing said the movie was based on a book by author Elly Conway. Later, they revealed Elly Conway is actually the main character of the movie. Itâ€™s hard to shift focus while keeping everything shrouded in mystery, and so people are wondering who wrote the tie-in novel, which is still credited to this fictional character. Could Taylor Swift have written it? J.K. Rowling, maybe?Â [Ed. note: I assume itâ€™s the cat, somehow.]

Instagram post by @samukarts

Akira Toriyama probably didn't write Argylle either.

The real supposition behind all these theories is that the movie has a story thatâ€™s too big for just a movie. It probably isnâ€™t, but since they spent $200 million on it, thatâ€™s exactly what theyâ€™re hoping. Thatâ€™s why I say thereâ€™s no going back. The hypertext must be the text now. The story youâ€™re watching has to go somewhere other than the screen or the page.

And beyond that, what caught my eye about the theories is the best guesses people can come up with are the most SEO-friendly figures in the cultural conversation. Something W. David Marx recently called â€œMacro-taste Micro cultureâ€ in a very interesting essay.

Itâ€™s disappointing to see the â€œBoss Baby vibesâ€ view of culture rushing to fill the tiniest vacuum of information, where every single unknown quantity will get more attention if you tie it into whateverâ€™s popular. â€œWas Argylle AI-generated?â€ Câ€™mon, crackpots!Â  Even with Elvis and JFK and so on, conspiracy theories used to require more effort and knowledge than this! Maybe the Bilderberg Group wrote it, I donâ€™t know.

If you want actual juicy gossip involving both fictional and real life spies, however, you should look up the directorâ€™s real name and why he goes by Matthew Vaughn instead. Truth is stranger than fiction, especially when the fiction is so interconnected that it ends up being about nothing while trying to be about everything.

I Do Not See The Vision

Long-time readers know that I am actually someone who thinks headsets are pretty neat. Iâ€™ve always been more bullish on augmented, rather than virtual, reality, however, largely because Iâ€™m still chasing the summer of 2016 PokÃ©mon Go high.

But after I spent a few weeks last year inside of Metaâ€™s Quest Pro, Iâ€™ve also become very attuned to the issues involving headsets. The main one being that if they donâ€™t easily sync with the other parts of your digital life, theyâ€™re actually a massive pain. About 30% of my experience inside the Quest Pro was taking it off to read my own passwords so I could type them into various accounts.

So I figured that the Vision Pro would fix this, seeing as how Appleâ€™s ecosystem is pretty damn good. But the first impressions Iâ€™ve seen from places like The Verge (embedded above) and YouTube creator Marques Brownlee, have not left me with a lot of confidence in Appleâ€™s new Vision (Pro). I mean the FaceTime stuff is hideous. And at this point, Iâ€™m honestly willing to say that I think the headset, as a concept, as weâ€™ve seen it, is completely wrong.

So whatâ€™s the way forward here? Well, Iâ€™m starting to wonder if the problem is that it shouldnâ€™t be one device, but two. What if, instead of cramming an entire â€œspatialâ€ computer into a headset, Apple made a pair of good XR glasses that plug in (or wirelessly connect) with their existing devices and then gave AirPods their own AI assistant?

Do People Actually Want AI Summaries?

The New York TimesÂ is hiring a generative-AI team. Based on the job listings, it looks like they may be researching the feasibility of building a proprietary ChatGPT-like chatbot for readers. (But thatâ€™s just me talking out of my ass.)

Also, The Browser Company, the folks behind the Arc Browser, which Iâ€™ve heard is pretty good (even if I once got in a fight on X with their founder), just released a new AI-powered â€œsearchâ€ app called Arc Search. As The VergeÂ put it, Arc Search, â€œcombines browser, search engine, and AI into something new and different.â€

a little Sunday surprise for you...

meet @browsercompany's 2nd product:

ğŸ”Arc SearchğŸ”

it's a default browser for your iPhone
...that BROWSES FOR YOU

the origin story is a bit unusual so I wanted to give you the full backstory:

â€” Josh Miller (@joshm)
Jan 28, 2024

But Arc Search, and whatever The New York Times may be exploring, along with the majority of other AI-powered â€œsearchâ€ platforms weâ€™ve seen so far are all built on two bizarre and weirdly unchallenged assumptions. That people both want to ask for information and also want to read summaries of said information.

Letâ€™s start with the first assumption: That people want to actively seek out news content. This is an especially weird idea that has seeped into Silicon Valley and, by extension, the increasingly-desperate mainstream media, considering that since the invention of the television, that has not been the case. In fact, almost all modern media is created to catch peopleâ€™s attention when they experience it out in the wild, whether thatâ€™s online in a feed or out in meatspace. Cable news, in particular, seems to be designed to exclusively catch your eye as you sit in an airport. So itâ€™s pretty silly to think that simply because an AI can talk to you at level on par with the average hiring manager on LinkedIn, that people will suddenly want to actively go and ask questions to consume the majority of their news. I think itâ€™s better to assume, at this point, that people just donâ€™t want to consume any news at all, unless itâ€™s being told to them by a young woman drinking flavored water out of a big lead-contaminated cup.

The second assumption, that people want summaries of information when they receive it, is also a funny one. It seems to come around every four-to-eight years. Typically when Democrats are in the White House, Iâ€™ve noticed. This was the impetus behind Vox, for instance, with its big initial claims of inventing â€œexplainer journalism,â€ which quickly just devolved into blogging, again. My own assumption here is that this is a byproduct of CEO brain. â€œI canâ€™t possibly read all of the information I need to pretend to care about to run my company, so other people must treat information as a nuisance to be fixed, as well.â€ But, once again, that is not really the case. The internet has turned the consumption of information into its own form of entertainment â€” or in the context of conspiracy theories, madness.

So, yeah, idk man lol. I think this is a dead end.

Pokimane Is Leaving Twitch

In last weekâ€™s paid issue, I wrote, â€œIâ€™m pretty blackpilled on [Twitch] at this point and Iâ€™m half-convinced that thereâ€™s no real way to turn the ship around. I think if one or two more big creators leave in the next six months, weâ€™re going to see a Snapchat-esque never-ending death spiral.â€

Well, a big creator is jumping ship much sooner than I expected. Imane Anys, known as Pokimane, announced that sheâ€™s leaving the platform yesterday. She has not said where sheâ€™s going next (if anywhere), but most folks seem to think itâ€™s YouTube.

I would say the death spiral for Twitch has officially begun.

Letâ€™s Talk About The Hazbin Hotel AMV Thing

The other day, I got a text out of the blue from a dear friend that, to paraphrase an old Tumblr post, felt as if I had just watched the outline of some great, unknown leviathan swim underneath the hull of my small ship. This was the text:

And, of course, I had to look up what this meant. And, yeah, itâ€™s exactly what it sounds like.

A YouTuber reportedly spent $50,000 commissioning an animated music video that features him in bed with a character from the cartoon Hazbin Hotel. If you want to see the video, you can find that here. Itâ€™s not NSFW, but itâ€™s also not SFW, if you know what I mean. But, also, my friend was right. The song in the video is pretty good. Itâ€™s called â€œHide Away,â€ by Synapson featuring Holly.
